loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna is married and has two grown children. She is a small entrepreneur from Zaporozhye. She sells children’s clothing in Angolenko, one of the busiest city markets. Anna owns 3 vending facilities in the same marketplace. She has been running this business for 15 years. Currently, she has about 70,000 Grivnyas in inventory. Her net profit is about 5,000 Grivnyas a month.

Anna is requesting a loan of 12,100 Grivnyas to purchase additional merchandise for the coming fall season. She is hoping to diversify her inventory and boost her sales as a result.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
Daisy J. is 47-year old rice grower in Norala, South Cotabato. She also raise pigs in her backyard. She started her business with only two piglets. Now, she has a sow and she sells piglets also to her neighbors and contacts. About her farm, she is managing a 2-hectare rice field. Farming really helps a lot in providing their family needs.

She needs additional capital. She is requesting a loan worth Php 10,000 to purchase feed, fertilzers and chemicals. She hopes that by having a loan to support her business, she will be able to grow her business all the more.

She actively participates in the CEVI cluster meetings. CEVI is not just giving loans to people but they also bringing education to all their clients to grow their business more.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, chemicals, and pig feed

loans.name: Norlinda

texts.en:
56-year-old Norlinda J. is growing rice to support her children. She was previously a mid-wife. But because she is old for the job, she ventured to the rice farming business to help support the needs of her family. 

Currently she has a 4-hectare farm. However, she needs additional capital to manage it well. She is asking for a loan of Php 10,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase fertilizer and chemicals.

CEVI helps small business grow. CEVI provides their clients like Norlinda with not just loans but education to run their business as well.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and chemicals

loans.name: Noemi

texts.en:
49-year-old Noemi O. helps her husband manage a 4-hectare farm. She was a former barangay health worker in their barrio. But because she wants to focus more on their farming business and help her husband as well, she quit her job. 

Now, she needs additional capital to buy fertilizer and chemicals. These are very important to ensure abundant and quality harvest on her farm.

CEVI is always helping farmers grow their livelihood in their village. That is why she chose CEVI because it does not only help people to avail loans but also gives education as well to grow their business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and chemicals

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
48-year-old Lorna E. owns a small rice field in their village. She has four children who are all studying and a husband, Leopoldo E., who manages their farm. It was in the year 1980 that they started farming. They have been doing the same thing because they are able to earn a better income from growing rice, which helped sustain their family for years now.

However, she is currently needing additional capital for her business. She would like to ask for a loan worth Php 10,000 to buy fertilizer and chemicals. She hopes that by making this move, she will be able to improve their harvest.

Lorna chose CEVI because of its services. She receives not just loans but education as well to run her business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and chemicals

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
42-year-old Gina P. is a rice farmer in Norala, South Cotabato. She has three children all studying in school and a loving husband who helps her manage their farm. She is tilling a 1 1/2- hectare farm that she inherited from her parents. The income that they get from the farm helps a lot in providing their children an education and other needs.

Now, she is asking for a little loan from CEVI worth Php 10,000. She will use her loan to buy fertilizer, chemicals and other farm necessities. 

She chose CEVI because they are not just there providing loans to people but education as well to help them manage their own business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and chemicals

loans.name: Fredisminda

texts.en:
Fredisminda J. is a 47-year-old mother of three children. She helps her husband, Emelito J., till their 5-hectare farm aside from the sari-sari store business that they have to be able to support the growing needs of their family. 

However, she still needs additional capital to manage their business well. She would like to ask for a loan worth Php 10,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fertilizer and chemicals as well as merchandise for her sari-sari store. 

Multi-business. This is what Fredisminda is doing. She learned it from her friends who are also availing CEVI credit services. CEVI provides her loans and education to help her manage and grow her business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and chemicals

loans.name: Mely

texts.en:
36-year-old Mely M. owns a 2-hectare farm in their village. She has five children and a loving husband, Abeniden M., who helps her manage their business. The farm is really a big help especially in providing for education and the other needs of her children.

She would like to ask for a loan worth Php 10,000. She will use the loan to buy fertilizer and chemical to ensure that she will have an abundant harvest on her farm.

Now, she actively involves herself in CEVI cluster meetings. She receives not just loans but training and insurance as well.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and chemicals

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
47-year-old Cecilia G. is growing rice to be able to help her husband support the needs of their family. She has three children studying. Her only wish is that she could send her children until college so that they will be able to find better jobs when they are older.

Now she needs a little help in her business. She would like to ask for a loan of Php 10,000 from CEVI to buy fertilizer and chemicals. These two are very important to ensure an abundant harvest on the farm.

She chose CEVI because of its wide services. CEVI is not just providing loans to people but also education to manage their business well.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and chemicals

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
62-year-old Corazon A. is a rice grower in their village. Although she is too old to farm, she is still strong enough to manage a business. She has five children. She and her husband, Asher A., work very hard to support their needs and their grandchildren.

She would like to ask for a loan of Php 10,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fertilizer and chemicals. The loan will truly help them achieve maximum harvest on their farm.

Now she is happy joining the CEVI credit program. She noticed that CEVI is not just providing loans to their clients but education as well to help their small business grow.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and chemicals

loans.name: Noralita

texts.en:
Noralita B. is a 61-year old widow who manages a rice farm. She started managing the farm last year. She was very sad and now the only thing she wants to do is make the farm productive in honor of her husband who passed away.

However, she needs additional capital to sustain her farm and would like a loan of Php 10,000. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers and chemicals. In this way, she can increase the size of her normal harvest.

Currently, she is connected with the CEVI credit program. She is happy because CEVI provides not just loans but education in how to make her small business grow.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and chemicals

loans.name: Minda

texts.en: 58-year old widow, Minda F., is a rice grower and store owner in Norala, South Cotabato. She has two children. Minda started her business in 2002 and still manages a farm and a sari-sari (variety) store because these are the things that help her provide all the needs in their family. Minda is requesting a loan of Php 10,000 which she will use to buy additional merchandise for her store. She will also buy fertilizers and chemicals for her farm. She believes that by buying these things, she will be able to surpass her normal sales in her store and harvest on her farm. CEVI helps Minda sustain her livelihood. CEVI clients are given not just loans, but education as well, to help their small business grow.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise for her store and fertilizers and chemicals for her farm

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce, a member of the Dodoma Roa C borrower group in Kihesa, Iringa, is a 36-year-old married mother of four children, ages 14, 11, 9, and 6 years. She also cares for one other dependent. Joyce started her own retail business selling charcoal eight years ago. Working eight hours a day, she earns a monthly profit of approximately 90,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This will be Joyce’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more charcoal, and with the additional profit accruing from the use of this loan, Joyce hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal.

loans.name: Naida

texts.en:
In order to help contribute to the family income, Naida J. owns and manages a small sari-sari store that sells variety goods in their village. With a supportive husband, she hopes that her business will help her child achieve as much education as possible. To boost family income, Naida is requesting a loan of Php 10,000 to buy more merchandise to attract a larger clientele.

She participates every time there is a CEVI cluster meeting in their barrio. In addition to loans, the CEVI program offers education that helps entrepreneurs effectively develop their businesses.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise.

loans.name: Eleseo

texts.en: Eleseo P., age 36, is a fisherman in Talibon, Bohol. He is starting to save money from his earnings, because he decided to get married early this year. He needs to repair his boat and buy fishing materials to carry on his fish-selling business. Since he knows well how to fish, he has good earnings which he shares with his parents and siblings. Eleseo actively participates in the CEVI cluster meeting which is held every week. CEVI provides its clients not just with loans, but with education as well, to help their small businesses grow.

loans.use: To buy fishing materials and for boat repair

loans.name: Flordeliza

texts.en: Flordeliza R., age 29, owns a tricycle transport. Her husband, Reynaldo R., is the one operating the tricycle to earn income for their family. She has one child who is studying in elementary school. Now, Flordeliza needs a loan to repair her tricycle. She is asking for a loan of 12,000 PHP from CEVI to buy the needed parts for her tricycle and to get started on a new business as well. Because she is looking for some other income sources, CEVI is helping her by providing credit assistance, education and insurance coverage.

loans.use: For tricycle repair and to start up a new business

loans.name: Isa

texts.en:
Isa was born in 1956. He is married and has four children. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of the Azerbaijan Fuzuli region. He is now settled in Fuzuli region, in the Bala Bahmanli village.

Eighteen years ago, he started his business. He sells medicines for animals. The drugstore is for animals. Now he needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy medicines for animals in order to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy medicines for animals

loans.name: Embakasy-B Group

texts.en:
Joyce is a member of the Embakasy-B borrower group in Ilala, Iringa. She is a 36-year-old woman. She is married and the mother of four children. Her children are ages 16, 11, 4, and 1 years. She also cares for two other dependents. 

Joyce started her own business selling snacks three years ago. She works five hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 55,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Joyce’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more wheat, cooking oil, etc. With the additional profit she will gain from the use of this loan, Joyce hopes to expand her business and save money. 

Agatha, another member of the Embakasy borrower group, has also requested 200,000 Tsh in order to support her own clothing business.

loans.use: To buy wheat and cooking oil

loans.name: Basdy

texts.en:
This woman is a mother with two children. She was born in 1973. Basdy is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of the Azerbaijan Fuzuli region. She has settled in the Fuzuli region, in the Zargar village.

Basdy has ten years of experience in her business. Now she needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy the foodstuffs for improving her business.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs

loans.name: Marianita

texts.en:
Marianita A., a 53-year old mother, is a rice grower. All of her children got married early, and it's she and her husband, Angelberto A. who live in their home. She wants to increase the normal size of their harvest.

She needs capital to buy fertilizers, rice seeds and chemicals needed to grow her farm. She thinks that by doing so, she can still support her children, and her grandchildren as well.

CEVI is helping her to achieve her dreams. She hopes that someday, she will be able to buy another hectare of farmland. With CEVI, she receives a loan, training and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, rice seeds and other chemicals

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Francisca D., 39, is helping her husband manage a small rice farm. She has five children, and the income that she gets from growing rice has helped her family with their needs. Currently, her farm needs fertilizers and chemical treatment. That is why she would like to ask for a loan of Php 7,000 from CEVI.

She hopes that someday, she will be able to attain better yield in her farm with the help of the fertilzers that she is going to buy. 

CEVI is helping her small business grow. Francisca receives not just loans, but education on how to run a business as well.

loans.use: To purchase farm fertilizers and chemical treatments

loans.name: Otavina

texts.en:
Otavina is a member of the Bondeni borrower group in Ilala, Iringa. She is 20 years old, married and the mother of one child. Her child is 1 year old.

Otavina started her own clothing business  clothes two years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 300,000 Tanzania Shillings (about $225).

This is Otavina’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Otavina hopes to get more food for her family and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Reynaldo

texts.en:
Reynaldo D. is a farmer. He is married but has no children yet. He wants to focus more on his business. All he wants to do is to buy another farm, but before he does that, he will make sure that he will have an abundant harvest from his existing farm.

For now, he needs additional capital for his business. He would like a loan of 7,000 PHP from CEVI. He will use the loan to buy fertilizers and farm chemicals. He is attending the CEVI cluster meetings. He has received not just loans, but education in running a business as well .

loans.use: To buy complete fertiliizers and farm chemicals

loans.name: Antonio

texts.en:
When Antonio T. inherited a rice farm from his parents, he was happy and confident that he would be able to make the farm productive. Now, he is 51 years old and still single. He wants to save money because he is still planning to get married, hopefully this year. He needs additional capital for his business. He would like a loan of 7,000 PHP from CEVI. He will use this loan in buying rice seeds, fertilizers and other farm needs.

Antonio is actively participating in CEVI cluster meetings where he learns about business and savings. He also receives insurance coverage in addition to the loans that he is requesting.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Rex

texts.en:
Pigs! This is what keeps Rex R. busy every day. He has been raising pigs since 1999. He started with four piglets; now he has five, six or more pigs in his backyard.

Rex would like to ask for a loan of 8,000 PHP from CEVI. He will use the loan to buy feed. He knows very well that feed is the only thing that makes his pigs grow; unfortunately, his money is not enough to buy the feed that is needed.

Like other clients, Rex receives not just loans from CEVI. He also receives education about savings and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is a member of the Dodoma Roa Dc borrower group in Kihesa, Iringa. She is a 27-year-old woman, married, and the mother of 2 children. Her children are aged 9 and 5. She also cares for 1 other dependent.

Lucy started her own shop selling rice, cooking oil, wheat, etc. 9 years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 180,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Lucy’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 300,000 Tsh in order to buy more commodities: rice,wheat, and sugar. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Lucy hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy  more merchandise for resale

loans.name: Zaujati

texts.en:
Zaujati is a member of the Bondeni borrower group in Ilala, Iringa. She is a 32-year-old woman, married, and the mother of 3 children. Her children are ages 9, 6, and 3.

Zaujati started her own charcoal and clothes business 10 years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 100,000 Tanzania Schillings.

This is Zaujati’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more charcoal. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Zaujati hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal

loans.name: Shadrack

texts.en:
Shadrack runs a firm by the name of Smartline Creations. The firm dealt with designing and printing communication materials. Last year, he lost his entire business as result of a tragic fire in the neighborhood. He has now changed focus and opened a décor and managing events business. He is married and has 2 children.

Shadrack's major challenge is lack of flower stands and enough fabric. He now wants a loan of Kshs. 50,000 to enable him to buy fabric and flower stands.

loans.use: Buy fabric and flower stands

loans.name: Cesiloa

texts.en:
Cesiloa is a member of the Tuamke borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is a 49-year-old woman, married, and the mother of 2 children. Her children are 20 and 18. She also cares for 1 other dependent.

Cesiloa started her own clothing business selling clothes, 5 years ago. She works 5 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 30,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Cesiloa’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes to sell. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Cesiloa hopes to expand her business, save money, and get more food for her family.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Tushikamane Group

texts.en:
Upendo is a member of the Tushikamane borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is a 26-year-old woman, married, and the mother of 1 child. Her child is 5 years old. She also cares for 2 other dependents.

Upendo started her own cafe business selling food, 4 years ago. She works 3 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 280,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Upendo’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 350,000 Tsh in order to buy more rice, wheat, etc. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Upendo hopes to save money and expand her business.

Rehema, another member of the Tushikamane borrower group, has also requested 350,000 Tsh in order to support her own cafe business.

loans.use: She will buy more rice, wheat, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Expand her business by buying more materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy 4 calves

loans.name: Winfrida

texts.en:
Winfrida is a member of the Kihodombi borrower group in Ilala, Iringa. She is a 29-year-old woman, married, and the mother of 3 children. Her children are ages 11, 9, and 6. She also cares for 2 other dependents. 

 Winfrida started her own tailoring business 3 years ago. She works 10 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 150,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Winfrida’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to  buy more material. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Winfrida hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more  material

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more material and a new sewing machine

loans.name: Fikret

texts.en:
"Dear friends! I need your help for improving my business again. I think that you have not forgotten me. Thank you very much! Good luck!" Fikret is applying for his second loan from Kiva. The first time he applied to Kiva in 2007, and he successfully repaid that loan.

Now he has his own butcher shop and he needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy meat to expand his business.

loans.use: to buy meat for sale

loans.name: Bandali

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 


Муродалиев Бандали родился 1957 году. Женат и имеет 4 детей. Уже около 5 лет как занимается предпринимательством. Он открыл свой цех в Торговом центре «Садбарг», где пекут хлеб. Основными заказчиками являются клиенты, которые торгуют на базаре. На запрашиваемый кредит он хочет купить  30 мешков муки и угля.

loans.use: Покупка 30 мешков муки и угля

loans.name: Isabela

texts.en:
Isabela is a member of the Upendo borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is a 48-year-old woman, married, and a mother of 7 children. Her children are ages 30, 24, 22, 18, 16, and 14. She also cares for 2 other dependents.

Isabela started her own clothing business, selling clothes like trousers, 5 years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 50,000 Tanzania schillings.

This is Isabela’s second loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 400,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Isabela hopes to get more food for her family, save money, and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Sarvinoz

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 


Сарвинозу 32 года. Замужем и мать 2-х детей. Она занимается продажей детской одежды. Она торгует на рынка «Станция» города Вахдат. Сарвиноз закупает товар из оптового рынка города Душанбе и часть товара из города Бишкек Республики Киргизстан. Она ездит за товаром 2-3 раза в месяц. Сарвиноз просит кредит для закупки новой партии летних детских одежд из хлопчатобумажной ткани.

loans.use: Закуп летних детских одежд

loans.name: Bingwa Njiapanda Group

texts.en:
Dorisi is a member of the Bingwa-Njiapanda borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is a 35-year-old woman, single, and the mother of 2 children. Her children are ages 14 and 8. She also cares for 3 other dependents. 

Dorisi started her own restaurant business selling food 2 years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 300,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Dorisi’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more commodities like wheat and rice. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Dorisi hopes to save money, get more food for her family, and expand her business. 

Anjelina, another member of the Bingwa-Njiapanda borrower group, has also requested 200,000 Tsh in order to support her own restaurant business.

loans.use: To buy more rice and wheat

loans.name: Magreth

texts.en:
Magreth is a member of the Singokele borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is a 31-year-old woman, married, and the mother of 2 children. Her children are ages 13 and 10. She also cares for 1 other dependent.

Magreth started her own clothing business selling clothes 5 years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 70,000 Tanzania schillings.

This is Magreth’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Magreth hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Assanansio's Group

texts.en: Assanansio K. is the leader of the Mpara group in Mubende. She is 32 years old and married with 6 children, ages 12 to 2, and she cares for 2 dependents. She has had a business of selling clothes from the daily markets of Mubende and Mityana for over 10 years now, and she wishes for her business to grow much stronger. She hopes to buy a car and start a hire service so as to reap big rewards. Assanansio needs to buy more clothes with the loan.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for resale

loans.name: Muzafar

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 


Олимов Музафар родился 1983 году, он недавно женился. Он занимается продажей мужской одежды.  Он торгует на рынке "Станция" г. Вахдат. Музаффар  закупает товар в оптовом рынке «Корвон» города Душанбе. Он ездит за товаром 2 раз в месяц. Музаффар хочет получить займ 3000 сомони сроком на 8 месяцев для закупа партий мужских спортивных костюмов.

loans.use: Закуп мужских спортивных костюмов.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is a member of the Bingwa-Njiapanda borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is a 32-year-old woman, married, and the mother of 3 children. Her children are aged 12, 8, and 3.

Judith started her own clothing business selling clothes 3 years ago. She works 10 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 300,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Judith’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Judith hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is a member of the Madizini borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is 25 years old and married. She cares for two dependents. 

Veronica started her own cafe business selling food a year ago. She works 11 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 200,000 Tanzania shillings (about $150).

This is Veronica’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more commodities for her business. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Veronica hopes to save money, to get more food for her family and to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities

loans.name: Kumriniso

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 




Кумринисо 6 лет торгует детской одеждой на рынке города Вахдат. У нее много постоянных клиентов. Ей 39 лет и у нее 3 детей. Она берёт кредит для расширения бизнеса продажи детской одежды. Привозит она товар из оптовых рынков. Для закупа летних маек для мальчиков и шорт она подала заявку на займ. Кумринисо на снимке на месте деятельности.

loans.use: Закуп летних детских одежд

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en:
Rukia is a member of the Twiga borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is a 27-year-old single woman.

Rukia has had her own business selling charcoal and soap for six months. She works for three hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 45,000 Tanzania shillings (about $34).

This is Rukia’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 150,000 Tsh in order to to buy more charcoal and soap. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Rukia hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal

loans.name: Patrick's Group

texts.en: M. Patrick is the leader of Nyamuhanamu group in Mubende. He is 37 years old and married with five children aged from four to twelve years, as he cares for three dependents. Since 1999 he has had a business selling alcohol in Nyamuhanamu, and he is able to make a monthly profit of 100,000 UGX. Patrick has future plans of building a family house and a house for rent so that he can have two businesses at the same time. He needs a loan to help buy and sell more alcohol for more profit. He says that the key to his success is his good customer care.

loans.use: To buy more alcohol for resale

loans.name: Johari

texts.en:
Johari is a member of the Kajificheni borrower group in Ilala, Iringa. She is fifty-eight years old and married with six  children, who are between the ages of twenty-nine and forty-two. She also cares for three other dependents. 

Johari started her own charcoal business ten years ago. She works twelve hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately $80.

This is Johari’s second loan from BRAC Tanzania, one of Kiva's field partners. She has requested 400,000 TSH in order to buy more charcoal. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Johari hopes to get more food for the family and to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal

loans.name: William's Group

texts.en: William is the leader of Bivamuntuuyo group in Mityana. He is a very hard-working man, and his retail shop has been his business for a long time. This is his tenth loan with the group. Since the beginning he has been able to build up his shop by increasing stock and capital. As a result, he has been able to pay school fees for his children, buy more plots of land for farming, and to have more cows and their milk to sell. He is proud of his lending group and he says he would do anything for it. He is applying for this loan in order to restock his shop with more products.

loans.use: To restock his shop with more goods.

loans.name: Ben's Group

texts.en: Ben K. is the leader of Balibaseka group in Mityana. He is a very hard-working man and a farmer with a business of buying and selling produce from Mityana town, sometimes to Kampala. He has been selling his produce, which ranges from maize and beans to coffee, for three years. His main challenge is transportation. Sometimes he uses bicycles or motorcycles, but he would like to buy a car so that he can load more kilograms of produce at once. Ben is married with twelve children, with three not yet in school, and he hopes that he will be able to educate all his children to the very end. He needs a loan in order to buy more produce to sell.

loans.use: To buy more produce for resale.

loans.name: Norah's Group

texts.en: Noral T. is the leader of Kibyamirizi group in Mubende. She is fifty-six years old and a widow with seven children. She also cares for three orphaned dependents. She has been in the business of buying and selling maize and beans from Kizinga since 1989, and she is able to make profits amounting to about $100 a month. Norah intends to build her own house in the future. In order to stop paying rent, she also wants a building where she can put her store. She needs a loan to help buy more bags of beans and maize for resale.

loans.use: To buy maize and beans to sell.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
ERLINDA U. is 55 years old, married with 6 adult children and a resident of Sitio Sutay, Pontevedra, Negros Occidental.

With such a big family, Erlinda and her husband have tried several business ventures over the years. They mostly farmed their small landholding which was very dependent on the whims of nature. It was not until Erlinda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001 that they were able to really experience more stability in their financial situation. She used her first cycle loan to start a "Sari-sari" store - the local version of a general store where everyone can buy anything and everything that has a demand within the area - from foodstuff like canned and baked goods to charcoal and kerosene gas for fuel and even some hardware and farm implements. She also went into food vending and even raised a few heads of cattle over the years.

She used her 11th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon to buy ducklings to raise. It proved to be a good venture to pursue that she invested most of her subsequent loans to this activity, and it now earns her family an additional PHP 2,000.00 per month. Erlinda's last loan of PHP 17,000 was paid off on time, and now she is borrowing PHP 22,000.00 for her 16th cycle loan to purchase more ducklings to raise and sell.

Raising ducks has not only proved to be a profitable activity for Erlinda and her family, the ducks are also very eco-friendly: they provide natural pest control by eating the insects and other pests in the fields, leave organic fertilizer and tamp down the weeds in the rice fields where they feed. 

Erlinda hopes that in the future, the business ventures that she and her husband started will be able to support the families of their children, and make life more comfortable.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: ducklings to raise and sell.

loans.name: Aurora Alexandre

texts.pt:
Aurora Alexandre N. nasceu na localidade de Ponta douro (sul da Província de Maputo fronteira com a Republica de África do Sul), tem 31 anos de idade e mãe de um filho de sete anos que frenquenta 2 classe na Escola primaria da vila da Ponta douro.
Aurora foi obrigada a ter que interromper os estudos na 5 classe para refugiar a áfrica do sul, devido à guerra civil que ocorreu no pais.

Após o ternimo da guerra (no ano de 1992) Aurora regressa aos pais juntamente com os seus pais e ano depois começa a ter uma relação com o seu marido. 
Aurora começou interessar se em fazer pequenos negócios. Em conversa com suas amigas, descobriu oportunidade de negocio e montou um pequeno salão de cabelaria para tratar de beleza das mulheres da zona.

Vive na casa própria com o seu marido e sem ninguém mais por sustentar. Nunca teve empréstimo com outros bancos (na ponta do ouro existe apenas a Hluvuku-Adsema com actividade crediticia) e que conheceu pessoalmente devido a sua localização estratégica, ao lado do mercado central.
Decide solicitar o primeiro credito no valor de 9.000,00MT para compra de material de construção e dar continuidade com a obra da sua casa que vem construindo em fases.

Para alem da cabelaria, possui também um mine estabelecimento comercial onde vende produtos de primeira necessidade. Tem um rendimento diário, proveniente das duas actividades, no valor de 1.500,00MT e conta com uma empregada no salão, enquanto ela cuida do principal negocio. ( venda de produtos de mercearia)
Propõe se a pagar bem o empréstimo para poder aceder a outros créditos para satisfazer o sonho de ter a casa concluída e prosperar no negocio.
texts.en:
Aurora Alexandre N. was born in Ponta douro (south of Maputo in the frontier with South Africa), she is 31 years old and has a 7 year old son, who is studying the 2nd grade at the elementary school in the village of Ponta Douro. Aurora had to interrupt her studies when she was on the 5th grade to get refuge in South Africa, because of the civil war in her country. After the war ended (in 1992) Aurora came back to her country with her parents and years later started her relationship with her husband. She lives in her own house with her husband. She never had a loan with other banks (in Ponta do Ouro there is just one Hluvuku-Adsema with credit activity) she learned about Hluvuku-Adsema in person due to its strategic position, near a central market. She decided to request a loan for 9,000MT to buy construction material to continue building her house in phases. Besides a beauty parlor, she has a grocery store where she sells basic needs products. She has a daily income of 1.500MT and she has an employee at the salon, while she takes care of the main business (selling merchandise). She expects to pay well the loan in order to access more loans to satisfy her dream of finishing her house and improve her business.

Translated from Portuguese by Nina Delgado, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy construction materials

loans.name: Baltazari

texts.en: Bartazari N. runs a retail shop where he sells clothing.  He sells both everyday and dress clothes of different designs for men, women and children. He purchases his clothing lines from wholesale shops in the Kariakoo city business center and sells to customers at his shop in Yombo Buzza ward in Dar es Salaam. He has been in this business for six years and his family depends on the income from the business for their daily needs. He is requesting a loan of 1,200,000 TZS to buy more clothing to sell.

loans.use: To buy more clothing to sell

loans.name: Paskazia

texts.en: Paskazia Victoria is a Tanzanian entrepreneur who runs a food shop at Yombo Buza Ward in Dar es Salaam.  She sells different types of food crop products. She purchases the products wholesale and retail, both directly from the producers and from the city markets. The goods Paskazia sells include wheat flour, maize flour, groundnuts, cashew nuts, cooking oil and sugar. The income from her business is used to meet her family's daily needs and for working capital. She needs a loan of 800,000 TZS to buy more goods to sell.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
38 year old Erlinda Montaño is married with 4 children aged 8, 10, 16 and 17. They live in the village of Pandan, in the town of Pontevedra, Negros Occidental. She is borrowing PHP 12,000.00 to buy fertilizer for the farm that she and her husband plant with sugarcane and rice, to supplement their family income and provide for their young family. 

Erlinda is very grateful that a friend invited her to join NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006, because the 7 loans she availed in the span of 3 years has had a great impact on their family. She used her first loan to start a "Sari-sari" store where she sold a wide variety of goods and products that were in demand in her neighborhood including the usual staples like rice, bread, salt and other stuff like laundry soap, shampoo, cooking oil, even charcoal and other fuel. 

With 4 children in school, the Montaño family needed a supplementary source of income. So Erlinda and her husband decided to diversify into rice and cane farming. Subsequent loans and profits from her store allowed them to buy a Carabao that they use to plow their cane and rice fields. The farm adds approximately PHP 2,000.00 per month to their family income.

Erlinda hopes that with diligence and continued determination, she will be able to raise her family to adulthood and provide a comfortable life for them.

The accompanying picture of Erlinda was taken inside Center No 96 of NWTF-Project Dungganon La Castellana Branch. 

About NWTF:
 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Felicita Regina

texts.es:
Felicita es socia del Bancomunal San Luís, es casada tiene 56 años y tiene cuatro hijos, el menor tiene 20 años y estudia en un instituto.
Felicita lavaba ropa pero era muy pesado, en su tiempos libres aprendió hacer mochilas  de peluche, y un día le regalo a una amiga por su cumpleaños, a su amiga le gusto y le pidió por docenas  para  venta, ella se dedica a la confección de mochilas y también a tejer carteras de hilo chompas, hace pedidos.
Desde que Felicita esta en Finca aprendió a ser mas sociable, era muy calada aprendió a esforzarse en el trabajo.
Felicita necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles, para la compra  de lanas al por mayor y de ropa de niños para venta.
El sueño de Felicita es de tener una tienda bazar.
texts.en:
Felicita is a member of the San Luís Communal Bank. She is 56 years old, married and has 4 children. The youngest is 20 years old and studying at an institute.

Felicita used to wash clothes for a living, but it was too much to handle. In her free time, she learned how to make plush satchels and gave one to a friend as a birthday gift. Her friend liked it so much that she asked to buy a dozen of them to sell. She now spends her time making satchels, as well as woven purses and sweaters upon request.

Since joining FINCA, Felicita has become more sociable. She was eager to learn as she put more effort into her work. Felicita needs a loan of 1000 soles, and will use it to buy wool at wholesale and children’s clothing for resale. She dreams of having her own store in the bazaar.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase wool at wholesale & children's clothing for resale

loans.name: Olga

texts.es:
Olga es socia del Bancomunal  San Luí, es conviviente tiene 44 años y tiene un hijo de 17 años que esta estudiando en la escuela estatal.
Olga estudio corte y confección y trabajo en un taller de costura por diez años, hasta que su hermano le regalo una remalladota y ella empezó a confeccionar buzos, gorras de natación, ella trabaja por contratos en colegios y cose buzos y cortinas.
Desde que Olga esta en Finca aprendió la importancia del ahorro y de tener dinero para emergencia que se puedan presentar en el negocio.    
Olga necesita un préstamo de 1800 soles, para compra tela de polar,  tela para  cortinas
El sueño de Olga es tener un taller de confecciones y comprase una maquina recta.
texts.en:
Olga is a member of the San Luí Communal Bank. She is 44 years old, in a common law marriage, and has a 17 year old son who is studying at a state school.

Olga studied tailoring and has been working in a sewing workshop for ten years. Her brother gave her an industrial sewing machine as a gift and she began making track suits and swim caps. She has contracts with a few colleges to make caps and curtains.

Since joining FINCA, Olga has learned the importance of saving and having enough money in case an emergency arises in her business. She is requesting a loan of 1800 soles, which will be used to buy fleece and fabric for curtains. Olga dreams of having her own clothing store and buying a straight-line stitching machine.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fleece & fabric

loans.name: Antonia

texts.es:
Antonia  es socia del Bancomunal  San Luís, es casada tiene 47 años, y tiene dos hijos de 22 y 12 años el ultimo esta estudiando en la escuela estatal.
Antonia estudio enfermería trabajo por mas de veinte años en  hospitales y centro geriátricos, hasta que decidió independizarse  ahora se dedica a cuidar pacientes particulares y se esta dedicando a tejer carteras de hijo y venta ropa y todo lo que le pidan.
Desde que Antonia esta en Finca, ha sido una  ayuda, por que le ayudo a crecer económicamente, ahora tiene ahorros. 
Antonia necesita un préstamo de 1800 soles, para invertirlos en la compra de un mueble y en la compra de ropa.
El sueño de Antonia es crecer y tener un puesto para vender ropa.
texts.en:
Antonia is a partner of Bancomunal San Luis, is 47 years old and married with two children. Her children are 22 and 12 years old, and her youngest is studying at the state school. Antonia studied nursing and worked for more than 30 years in hospitals and in homes for the elderly, until she decided to become independent and now she works taking care of individual patients. She is dedicating herself to knitting bags and the sale of clothing, as well as anything else that her patients ask for. Since Antonia has been in the land, she has been a help because she has helped with economic growth, and now she has savings. Antonia needs a loan of $600 to invest in the purchase of furniture and clothing. Antonia's dream is the grow and have a stand to sell clothing.

Translated from Spanish by Amy Schapiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of furniture and clothing

loans.name: Ana Virginia

texts.es: Doña virginia es originaria de la comunidad de Totonicapan  su actividad economica es la marraneria viene ejerciendo dicha actividad cuando tenia catorce años, sus principales puntos de ventas son San cristobal Toto los dias Domingos, sabados y martes en la ciudad de Totonicapan y los dias jueves Salcaja Quetzaltenango en la venta de chicharrones de marrano y sus derivados hoy necesita de un credito por la sencilla razon en busca de otros mercados principalmente momostenango en la plaza de los dias jueves con la utilidad le permite satisfacer la necesidad de su familia.
texts.en:
Doña Virginia is originally from the community of Totonicapan. She operates a pig farm, which she first learned to do when she was 14 years old. She sells chicharrones (fried pork skins) and other pork products. The primary locations where she sells are San Cristobal Toto on Sundays and Saturdays, Totonicapan on Tuesdays, and Salcaja Quetzaltenango on Thursdays.

She needs a loan for the simple reason of opening new markets, primarily in Momostenago Square on Thursdays. She hopes this will meet the needs of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase operating capital

loans.name: Jose Manuel

texts.es: El es originario de la comunidad de paqui con cariño le dice don manuelito su principal fuente de ingreso es la venta de productos diario, hoy necesita de un credito la cual sera invertido en la compra de tarjetas telefonicas  de las diferentes compañias, por ser una de las demandas de los jovenes y señoritas por dicho lugar se encuentra un instituto por cooperativa, la cual el manifiesta que debe de aprovechar  esa occaccion para poder mejora su nivel de vida y la de su familia con la venta.
texts.en:
He is from the Paqui community. Manuelito affectionately explains that his primary source of income is from selling daily needs products. He now needs a loan to buy telephone cards from different companies. They are in demand by the young men and young ladies from the cooperative institute near his place. He feels he should take advantage of this sales opportunity to be able to improve his level of life and his family’s.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy articles of daily consumption

loans.name: Badarch

texts.en:
Badarch C. is a 66-year-old widowed mother. Together with her grandson, Lhasuren, age 18, she lives in a ger (nomadic tent housing) district in Arhangai, one of Mongolia's central provinces. In 1999, her eldest daughter, who has three children, was widowed. Since then, Badarch decided to help her daughter by starting to run a small business selling household items such as soap and glue. Basically, she sells whatever can be sold.

When Badarch started her retail business, her working capital was 60,000 tugrugs (that is ~ $40 US). As a result of her hard work, the working capital has increased 1,900,000 tugrugs. With the profit, she has been paying her grandchildren's tuition. She requests a loan to purchase small household items from Ereen, a Chinese border city.

loans.use: To purchase small household items to resell

loans.name: Bayanbat

texts.en:
Since 2007, Bayanbat T. has been running a small cafe together with his spouse, Chimgee, in a rental place near the local market. He has two employees. Bayanbat is a 22-year-old married father of one. His family lives in a ger (nomadic tent housing) district in Arhangay, one of Mongolia's central provinces.

With his profit, he maintained and expanded his cafe last year. This couple hopes to have their own business place as soon as their business is quite successful. During the last three years, Bayanbat's working capital has increased from 500,000 tugrugs to 1,200,000 tugrugs ($1 US = ~1450 MNT). He requests a loan to purchase flour, rice, whole animal meat and vegetables for his business. He says, "My wish is to keep my only son healthy and help him become a good person."

Thanks, Bayanbat - an open, cheerful and hardworking person!

loans.use: To purchase flour, rice, whole animal meat and vegetables for a cafe

loans.name: Bulgantamir

texts.en:
Z. Bulgantamir, 44, is a single mother who has twin girls aged 11. Both her children are attending a local elementary school.

In 1999 Bulgantamir started running a retail business selling sheep, goat and cow organs at the local butcher shop. Her two friends have helped her very much to start the business. As a result of Bulgantamir's 10 years of hard work, her inventory has increased from 400,000 tugrugs to 4,000,000 tugrugs (1 USD=1450 MNT).

During the last few years, Bulgantamir has been purchasing whole animal carcasses at wholesale prices then cutting them up to resell at retail prices. With the profit, she bought a plot of land four years ago. Last year she built a small house on the plot of land she owns.

During the interview, Bulgantamir said that "I'm working hard for my daughters' future prospects. My hope is to let them enroll in university and provide financial support for them to pay their tuition."

With this loan, Bulgantamir will buy whole animal carcasses for her business.

loans.use: To buy whole animal carcasses for her business

loans.name: Byambasuren

texts.en:
Byambasuren G. is a 64-year-old widow. She lives with her daughter, Oyunbileg, age 27, in Arhangai, which is one of the central provinces of Mongolia. In 1998, she looked for a better life and, therefore, moved to Arhangai Province. As soon as she moved, she started running a tailoring business from home.

Byambasuren gets orders from local residents and herders to sew a "deel," the Mongolian traditional dress, or she makes the deels first and then sells them. During the university graduation ceremony that is held in the spring, she gets a lot of orders from students. Her daugher, Oyunbileg, helps in her mother's business in addition to working as a teacher at a local elementary school.

Byambasuren makes the deels from cotton and a variety of silks. She is requests a loan to purchase raw materials for her business. She hopes to have her own working place in hear future and then expand her business by hiring employees, because she is getting more and more sewing orders.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for her sewing business

loans.name: Byambasuren

texts.en:
Byambasuren C. is a 59-year-old widow. She lives with her daughter and two granddaughters in a rented place in Arhangai, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her grandchildren attend local elementary schools and her daughter runs a small business at the local market.

In 2008, Byambasuren started a catering business. She makes a variety of traditional meals and sells them to a local retailers. Her clients are mostly salesman and woman who have a stalls at the local market. She purchases meat, vegetables, rice, and flour for 20,000 tugrugs (equal to $ 14 USD) every day and makes around 40-50 dishes per day.

She says "I'm getting experiences pretty much. So I'm started thinking to rent a small space at the market and open my own cafe since my clients are like to have a meal i cooked for them".

With this loan, she will buy whole animals for meat for her tiny business, because meat is cheapest during the summer.

loans.use: To buy whole-animal meats

loans.name: Dulmaa

texts.en:
Dulmaa N. is a 39-year-old single woman. She lives on a plot of land that she owns in a ger district (a community of yurts) in Arhangay, one of the Mongolian central provinces.

In 2007, Dulmaa opened a food stall at the Tsahiur local food market. She sells mostly bottled and canned foods and biscuits. Dulmaa purchases the food in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city, at wholesale prices, and then resells them at a retail prices to local residents.

Dulmaa is a humble, hard-working lady. With her future profits, she plans to have her own stall, instead of her current rented stall. With this loan, she will purchase a variety of food products for her business.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of food products for her business.

loans.name: Allah Muhammad Group

texts.en:
Allah M. is the leader of the Allah M. loan group. There are three members in this group. Each of them wants a loan to expand their business and make it larger, so they are requesting a group loan of 30000 Afghani.

Allah M. wants a loan for his burger and ice cream shop. Hanesa wants a loan for her tailoring business. Torpayki wants a loan for her husband who has an ice cream shop. They are happy that this loan process can support all entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Valerie

texts.en:
After overcoming many hardships, including the loss of her husband to gun violence in 2002, Valerie has finally achieved her long-time dream of owning her own business.

Valerie is the owner of SPA-bulous! A Spa Retreat for FA-bulous Women! in Hayward, CA. SPA-bulous! is a place for women to rejuvenate themselves and also receive education on personal well-being. Valerie has a passion for helping women and keeps the spa open in the evening and weekends to give working mothers access to her services. In addition, SPA-bulous! donates free services to fundraisers for breast cancer, domestic violence, and other charities close to Valerie’s heart.

A single mother, Valerie continues to raise her three-year-old son, work a full time job, and run her business, while trying to complete her bachelor’s degree this fall. She also mentors other single mothers to stay motivated and keep their dream alive.

A $3,000 loan will allow Valerie to replace broken equipment at her spa, such as a steamer and facial bed.

loans.use: Replacement equipment for spa services

loans.name: Zarmena Group

texts.en:
Zarmena is the group leader of Zarmena group. There are three members in this group. They live in district 11 and they are requesting a group loan of 15,000 Afghani to increase their income and progress their businesses.

Zarmena wants to take a loan for her hairdressing business. She wants to buy cosmetic things for her business. Fazelah wants to take a loan for her embroidery business. Fowzya wants to take a loan for her tailoring business. She wants to buy new machine for her business. They are very happy with this small loan in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To make their businesses larger

loans.name: Tahseen

texts.en:
Tahseen is 28 years old. He is a single man living with his parents and he helps them to pay for his four younger siblings' education.

After trying his luck with several different businesses, Tahseen decided to fully dedicate himself to selling shoes and slippers. This activity has helped him overcome economic obstacles and has helped his parents educate and feed his younger brothers and sisters.

Today, Tahseen needs a loan of 2,000 US Dollars to increase his inventory in order to meet the demands of his customers.

loans.use: To buy more shoes to sell

loans.name: Sarangerel

texts.en:
Sarangerel D. is 52 years old, married, and the mother of two. Her family lives in a "ger" (nomadic housing tent) district on the plot of land her family owns in Arhangai, one of the Mongolian central provinces.

Sarangerel’s husband, Altangerel, has already retired. Before he retired he had been working at a local mining operation for twenty-seven years. He runs a small carpentry shop to increase his family income since their only grandson has suffered a stroke. Most of their income is spent on their grandson's treatment.

Sarangerel is a professional chef. She worked in a tourist camp as a chef between 2005 and 2007. Further, she rents a small cafe that is located in a hotel. Since her cafe business is quite successful, she decided to rent another place to open another small cafe near the main interstate road. This loan will help her to open this small cafe. Sarangerel says that "our dream is for my beloved grandson to get fully recovered."

loans.use: To open another small cafe

loans.name: Anwar

texts.en:
Anwar is a 34 year-old married man with five children. Anwar owns a grocery store and provides for his family with the revenue generated by it. Currently he is seeking a loan of 2,500 USD to purchase more inventory so he can increase the variety of goods he offers.

Anwar had some struggles when his business was growing and becoming self-sustainable, but he handled all those challenges pretty well and is looking toward the future with much enthusiasm and optimism.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Zagdsuren

texts.en:
Zagdsuren N. is a 49 year old married woman who has three children. She is a professional barber. She used to work for a privately held company as a barber. As her clients are very satisfied with her haircut service, she thought it would be more profitable if she opened her own barber shop. In 1990 she opened a small barber shop near the local market and now she has many repeat clients.

Zagdsuren says that "I couldn't let my two eldest daughters graduate from university because of our family's inability financially. Thus I really want my youngest one to graduate from the university. I've already started saving small amounts for my youngest one's tuition." With this loan she will buy a hair dryer and other equipment for her barber shop.

loans.use: To buy hair dryer and other equipment for her barber shop.

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida M. is 51 years old and mother to two adult-aged daughters. She lives in the mountainous city of Antipolo, Rizal province, in the Philippines. Her husband, Feliciano, is 73 years old and her partner in a general store business. Zenaida is a determined and courageous woman whose main goal is for her family to step out of poverty.

Zenaida has been running a general store for four years. In 2005 she joined ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, because she sometimes encountered shortage in her capital. Now that she has the opportunity and access to capital, her business runs well with the help of her husband and children. She is now requesting a loan of 30,000 PHP to pay for 15 sacks of charcoal, 5 sacks of rice, 12 cases of beers and soft drinks, and other groceries for her store.

Zenaida is hopeful that her loan, partnered with hard labor and industry, could lift her family up and away from the wall of poverty. With the proceeds she makes, she dreams of having a durable and spacious house, and hopes to extend her business in the years to come.

loans.use: To buy 15 sacks of charcoal, 5 sacks of rice, 12 cases of beverages, and groceries

loans.name: Cheriben

texts.en:
Cheriben G. lives in the city of Antipolo, Rizal province, in the Philippines. She is married to Ronnie, who is 51 years old and also her business partner. She has six children and, as a mother, she hopes only for what is best for her children.

The hope of getting out of the spiral of poverty brought Cheriben to join ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, in 2007. She has been running a business selling chickens for ten years. Now on her fourth loan, Cheriben is requesting the amount of 20,000 PHP as additional capital for her business – 15,000 PHP of her loan will be used as capital in the purchase of chickens while the remaining 5,000 PHP will be used for other expenditure, such as transportation. Cheriben's business is successful and it gives her family a good profit on which to live. As a mother, Cheriben aspires to send her younger children to school and have them find jobs. She also hopes to have a durable house and the opportunity to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy chickens for resale and meet other costs such as transportation

loans.name: Marita

texts.en:
Marita L. hails from the beautiful city of Antipolo, Rizal Province, in the Philippines. She is 35 years old and the mother to four. All of her kids are all in the elementary grades except the youngest, who is four years old. Her husband, Rogelio, is 39 and is a vendor and her business partner.

Life was not easy for Marita. She was challenged by the miserable condition of their lives to strive hard and search for a greener living. In 2003, she joined ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, with the hope of bringing light to her family. On her previous loans, she prudently invested those in doormat making. But it is quite laborious and time consuming.

Just recently, Marita opted to venture in fish-ball vending which is in demand by kids and also by the people in the community, especially during the afternoon. She observed that fish-ball vending is more profitable, and so she considered it as their primary business.

Now, Marita has applied for a loan of 30,000 pesos as additional capital for her business, to improve her cart and some will go to her secondary business of doormat making.

Marita is positive and hopeful that, if coupled with industry, their business will bring them great profit so that they can save and be able to send their children to school, enabling them to find jobs.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for fish-ball vending and doormat making

loans.name: Murad

texts.en:
Murad is a married, 40-year-old father of three children. He owns and operates a printing house in Ramallah city in Palestine, where he provides all types of printing services with the help of several employees.

Murad is seeking a loan in the amount of $3,000 USD so that he may invest in additional paper, ink, and printing machine parts to further expand his business. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To improve and expand his printing business by purchasing paper, ink, and machine parts

loans.name: Demberel

texts.en:
Demberel T. is a 34-year-old married mother of one daughter. Her family lives in a "ger" (yurt) district in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Her only daughter, Munhzul, age 13, attends a local elementary school. Demberel's husband, Erdenbaatar, is a hard worker in South Korea.

Since 2000, Demberel has been running a butcher stall at the Narantuul, the biggest food market in the capital city. Her sister ran a butcher shop when Demberel decided to open a retail business 9 years ago. Then her sister helped her to start this business. She purchases whole animal meats, especially beef, at wholesale prices and then cuts the meat and resells it in her stall.

Demberel's dream is to expand her small business by opening a bigger butcher shop that sells a variety of meats, including sheep, goat, mutton and camel meat. She is requesting a loan to purchase whole beef to increase her business inventory.

loans.use: To purchase whole beef for her business

loans.name: Ganbold

texts.en:
Ganbold C. is a 37-year-old married man who has one daughter. His only daughter, Bolortuya, age 19, is a university student. His family lives in a condominium that he owns in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia.

Ganbold makes sofas and sells them at the Narantuul market, the biggest four-season outdoor market in the capital city. He purchases unprocessed wood, cotton and other raw materials for 150,000 tugrugs (~ $100 USD) per sofa. Then he sells each sofa for 220,000-230,000 tugrugs (~$150 - $160). He makes 10 sofas per month on average and sells all of them.

Ganbold's wife, Purevsuren, helps in her husband's business. She usually works as a saleswoman at the Narantuul market. With the profits, Ganbold has purchased a plot of land. With future profits, he is planning to build a house on the land he owns next year. He is requesting a loan to buy raw materials to increase his business inventory.

loans.use: To buy raw materials

loans.name: Otgonbat

texts.en:
Otgonbat T. is a 38-year-old married woman who has two children. Her family lives in a "ger" (yurt) district in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Both of her children go to the local elementary school. 

In 2000, she started a retail business selling costume jewelry, such as earrings, necklaces, and rings, for teenage girls. Her stall is near the central door of the Narantuul market, the biggest four-season outdoor market in the capital city. Because of its location, at least 10% of market visitors stop by her stall, and most of them purchase some of the small items that she sells. Once or twice a year, Otgonbat goes to Ereen, a city on the Mongolian-Chinese border, to purchase more small accessories at wholesale prices. To save travel expenses, she asks her friends who go to Ereen to buy goods for her. 

With the profits from her business, her husband has built a house on the plot of land they own. Otgonbat says, "Because my husband and I are very busy, we cannot take good care of our children. Thus, we are planning to hire a saleswoman for our business. I hope, then, that we can spend more time with our children." 

Otgonbat is requesting a loan to purchase goods for her small business.

loans.use: To purchase costume jewelry for her business

loans.name: Valarie

texts.en:
After overcoming many hardships, including the loss of her husband to gun violence in 2002, Valarie has finally achieved her long-time dream of owning her own business.

Valarie is the owner of SPA-bulous! A Spa Retreat for FA-bulous Women! in Hayward, CA. SPA-bulous! is a place for women to rejuvenate themselves and also receive education on personal well-being. Valarie has a passion for helping women and keeps the spa open in the evening and weekends to give working mothers access to her services. In addition, SPA-bulous! donates free services to fundraisers for breast cancer, domestic violence, and other charities close to Valarie’s heart.

A single mother, Valarie continues to raise her three-year-old son, work a full time job, and run her business, while trying to complete her bachelor’s degree this fall. She also mentors other single mothers to stay motivated and keep their dream alive.

A $3,000 loan will allow Valarie to replace broken equipment at her spa, such as a steamer and facial bed.


To learn more about SPA-bulous! visit the website at: www.spa-bulous.com

loans.use: Replacement equipment for day spa

loans.name: Teodosia

texts.en:

To make a living, Teodosia owns and operates a business raising livestock and raising fish to sell. Teodosia has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2007, Teodosia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teodosia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. Teodosia is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Teodosia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

texts.en:

Mornh R. has been selling a few fresh fish in the local busy market for more than nine years. She sells fish that she gets fR. her husband’s fishing or buys them fR. her wholesale supplier and other fishermen.

Mornh R. finds it hard, transporting fish to sell at the market, because she doesn’t have her own vehicle and she hopes to buy one. Due to the lack of money, she requested a loan to add to her savings to buy a used motorcycle which she will use for picking up fish and for her family's traveling needs.

loans.use: To buy a used motorcycle for picking up fish and for her family's traveling needs

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital.

loans.name: Tem

texts.en: Tem P. is 52 years old and sells hammocks in the Takeo province. Her business has been around for about eight years and she makes US$2.5 every day. Her husband is a carpenter who typically generates about US$3 of profit to help support the family. This couple has two children, one of whom is a student and the other one is a worker. Tem is asking for a loan of US$500 to purchase more hammocks to sell. She sees this investment as opportunity that will be able to increase her daily income. (Tem P. is pictured, with her husband, from home).

loans.use: To purchase hammocks.

loans.name: Anacorita

texts.en:
Anacorita S., 54 years old, is from the village of Kauswagan. She is married and has 3 adult children. Anacorita owns & operates a handicraft business selling general handicrafts to tourists and local community members. Anacorita has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2000, Anacorita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Anacorita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Anacorita is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP to be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Anacorita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: This small grocery shop is used by Sok P., age 39, for selling groceries to earn a living. She sells items that she buys in bulk on credit from her wholesale supplier and then retails in the village for her neighbors. She typically generates an income of around $2 to manage her family’s living expenses. She was married but divorced her husband and currently has two children who are working in the fishing sector. Sok P. will be using her loan to buy a boat and some fishing equipment to help support her children’s fishing activities.

loans.use: To buy a boat and some fishing equipment

loans.name: Annie

texts.en: Annie A. recently joined PMPC to gain access to the various programs and services of the Cooperative. She has been operating a general store for 5 years that she would like to expand. She has not been able to access financing for her business expansion.  She is 46 years old, married and has 3 children. She is thankful that PMPC is willing to finance her purchase of additional inventory. She desires to live a good life in the near future and she would like all of her children to finish schooling in their chosen fields.

loans.use: To purchase additional product to sell.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda I., 56 years old, is from the village of Biasong. She is married and has 6 adult children. Erlinda operates a fishing business. She makes her living harvesting & selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Erlinda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Erlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase fishing equipment, including hooks & nets. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP to be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Erlinda from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Rosenita

texts.en:
Rosenita M. is running a general store in San Isidro Bajo selling a variety of different products. She is 42 years old, married and blessed with 2 children. She has enjoyed selling products in her store for 10 years already and she is able to earn PHP 2,600 per month.

She joined PMPC to request her 1st loan to purchase additional products to sell. She wants to start saving money from her earnings and she hopes to see all of her children finish their degrees.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda I. is from the village of Biasong. She is 56 years old. Erlinda is married and has six adult children. Erlinda operates a fishing business. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (about $104) a month for these activities.

In 2007, Erlinda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fishing equipment, including hooks and nets. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Erlinda from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Touch

texts.en:
Touch T. is 36-years old. He lives in Takeo province with his wife who sells roast beef. He has three school-aged children.  To make a living, Touch has a middle-man business selling motorbikes and he has been in this business for over six years. Touch earns approximately 20,000 riel or about US $5 a day.  His wife makes about US $3 per day to help support the family.

Touch joined CREDIT MIF to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and improve his ability to engage in business activities. Touch is requesting his first loan from CREDIT of US $1000. This loan will be used to invest in expanding the business. (Touch is pictured with his wife at home)

loans.use: To purchase motorbikes

loans.name: Badamhand

texts.en:
Badamhand B. is a widow with two children aged 28 and 22. Her family lives in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city. In 2002, Badamhand started running a butcher stall in Huchit shonhor, the local food market. She buys sheep meat for 800,000 - 1,000,000 tugrugs ($1 USD = 1450 MNT) from the wholesale centers on a daily basis and resells all of them on same day.

Besides selling meat through the stall, she also provides a few restaurants and cafes with their daily meat needs. Her youngest son Bat-Erdene is a university student. After his classes he helps his mother's retail business.
