*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair the vehicle that he uses for his transport service

loans.name: Justine

texts.en:
Justine R. is engaged in a fruit-juice-processing business in the rural area of Santos Quezon, Isabela. She makes and processes vinegar and fruit juice and she also manages a hog-raising business in her backyard. She sells her processed products in stores in her village.  

Justine wanted to increase her capital, so she is asking for financial support from Kiva of PHP 11,000. The continuous support of Kiva lenders and the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) will allow her to improve her business and expand her customer base. She also hopes that her business will provide jobs for the unemployed some day.

Justine is married to Renie R. who has a thriving tricycle-based transport business. They are blessed with two children who are in high school. In the meantime, their children serve as their helpers to deliver their products to stores on weekends. Justine is happy that her family helps to fulfill their dreams in life.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Tumurpurev

texts.en:
Tumurpurev S. is 27-year-old and lives with his 22-year-old wife and daughter in Arhangai Province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. His daughter is just 2-year-old and stays home with her mother. 

Tumurpurev is a talented carpenter. He makes various items of furniture, including tables, chairs, and beds. Since he opened his  business in 2005, he has been doing great and expanding his business. His business capital has increased from 200,000 MNT (~ $140) to 800,000 MNT ($550). With his business profits, he was able to purchase a small piece of land with a small house for his family. He says that he would like to expand his business and make better quality furniture for locals. 

He is requesting a loan to purchase cut wood for his carpentry business.

loans.use: To purchase cut wood for his carpentry business.

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Violeta O. is a hardworking vendor who lives simply in the village of Santos Quezon, Isabela. She is married to Renato O., who is a farmer. Their major livelihood in the village is agriculture. Rice, vegetables and bananas are their main products that they produce every year. To help her husband earn a daily income, Violeta ventured into selling their produce. She sells in the market and sometimes in their neighborhood. When her products do not sell in the market, she often sells them to her neighbors in the village at a cheaper price. She enjoys her business and tries her best to improve it.  

With the opportunity brought by Kiva lenders, Violeta is encouraged to apply for a loan of  PHP 12,000 that she will use as additional capital for her vending business. She will then able to support small vegetable farmers in their village by selling their fruit and vegetable products in the market and to local villagers. 

She hopes that Kiva lenders will pay attention to her business concerns and ambitions, not only for herself, but also for her fellow man.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Tuvshinbayar

texts.en:
Tuvshinbayar M. is 23 years old and lives with her parents in Arhangai Province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. She has a small retail business selling clothing. With her business profit, she looks after her parents. Her parents have been in the retail clothing business since 1995. Since the beginning, she helped in her parents' business. 

In 2002, she has started her own retail business by selling various men and women clothing and small household items at the Hasu Shopping Center, one of the largest shopping centers in the town. She currently rents three stalls at the shopping center. She sells products that she brings from Ereen, China, a border town where many cheap Chinese products are exported to Mongolia. She says that becaue her business is the sole family income, she works hard to make her living and look after her parents.
 
She is requesting a loan to purchase more clothing and small items for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing for her business

loans.name: Glody

texts.en:
Glody M. is 40 years old. She has nine children ranging in age from 3 to 20 years old. She is married to Danilo Moteno, a 50-year-old fisherman. Glody and her family live in the North Peninsula of Antique, which is in Pandan. The place is rich in natural resources. Pandan is surrounded by verdant mountains and a blue ocean that sparkles during the day time. 

Having been trained in cosmetology, such as manicures, pedicures, hair cutting, and hair curling, Glody has been practicing her trade for the last three years. This has been her business and her source of income. With the profits from her business, she has helped her husband to augment the family income. 

Glody's ASHI loan has supported her business and her husband's fishing business. Because she was able to repay her first loan, she is now qualified to apply for another loan for a higher amount. She plans use this loan, and future loans, to invest in her growing business. She wishes that some day she will own a beauty shop in their village where she can give her custumers comfort and good quality services.

Glody hopes that all of her children will graduate from college. That is why she wants her business to succeed. Her loan from ASHI is a very important factor that could lead her toward fulfillment.

loans.use: Cosmetic products

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita L. hails from the mountainous city of Antipolo, Rizal Province in the Philippines. She is full of hope that she can raise her family out of poverty. She is 44 years old and is married to Rogelio, her business partner. They have been blessed with six children. Her eldest son is 24 years old and the youngest is a 4-year-old boy.

Her greatest aspiration in life is to provide a decent life for her children. In 2000, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, with a bagful of hope to step out from under the burden of poverty. She invested some of her previous loans in the raising of hogs, but years later, she opted to shift her business to transportation with a tricycle and rickshaw.

The business went smoothly and brought them enough profit, because the tricycle transportation is in demand in the city. Now on her 14th loan, she proposes the amount of 20,000 pesos. With it, she will renew her business license and pay for tires and other maintenance for the tricycle. She will use part of her loan as capital for her secondary resale business.

She is optimistic that, with the help of ASHI and KIVA, she can achieve her dreams of sending her children to school and expanding her business.

loans.use: To renew her license and buy tires and other maintenance for the tricycle.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou L. is the 47-year-old manager of her own business. She is full of industry and hard work, and is aiming to pull her family out of poverty. She is married to Teodoro, who is 53 years old and her business partner. She is the mother of seven children, three of whom are still of underage and dependent on her. She lives in Antipolo City, Rizal Province in the Philippines.

In 1999, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, with a bagful of dreams to alleviate the poor conditions of her family. Her previous loans were carefully spent on her sari-sari (variety) and food store. The business went well and smoothly. She has many regular customers and the business has brought good proceeds that she can use for her family's needs.

Now on her 15th loan, she proposes the amount of 45,000 pesos to pay for sacks of rice, charcoal, feed, fresh pork, and other groceries for her store. She is positive that her business will grow large and bring her income so she can save for the future of her younger children. She is also looking forward to expanding her business.

loans.use: To pay for sacks of rice, charcoal, feed, fresh pork, and other groceries for her store

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria J. is a 58-year-old woman from the city of Antipolo, Rizal Province in the Philippines. She is married to Geraldo, who is 60 years old and a jeepney driver. She lives only with her husband; they don’t have children.

Despite of having no child, she is still fighting poverty. She dreams of having a sustainable business that meets their needs and allows them to save for their future, since they are getting old. 

Victoria sells cement. In 2005, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, hoping to access capital for her business. Her previous loans were used as rolling capital business. Now on her 7th loan, she proposes the amount of 20,000 pesos as additional capital for her business. The loan will be used to buy open bags of cement for 9,000 pesos and closed bags of cements for 11,000 pesos. She hopes that the business will bring them good profits.

loans.use: To buy cement to sell

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia D. is 47 years old, the same age as her husband, Felix. The couple have three children, ages 21 to 26. Their eldest child is a computer programming graduate and the other two are college undergraduates who are working as laborers.

Lydia, her husband, and their children had been living in Manila. Lydia's husband worked in a manufacturing shop that made household furniture from native materials, such as ratan. She sold relief goods, such as clothing, shoes, and bags, to people in their village. Felix received only a small profit from his output despite the hard work it entailed. Lydia's business was unstable because she did not have sufficient business capital. Because Lydia and Felix felt that they could not afford to live in Manila with its high standard of living and still send all of their children to college, they decided to return to their own province in Antique.

Because Felix had experience in furniture-making, enhanced by years of working in Manila, he and Lydia thought of opening their own furniture shop in the Province. Lydia agreed to her husband's idea and she was delighted once again, because she can have still her own business buying and selling relief goods while partnering with her husband in the furniture business. A small amount of savings and a loan from ASHI enabled Lydia and her husband open a shop in their house in Patria, Pandan. They hired one of Felix coworkers from Manila to work with them. 

Lydia believes that, someday, her loan from ASHI will make their business successful because she maintains an excellent record of repayment and attendance at center meetings. Her attitude is as fine as their manufactured furniture, which attracts potential customers. Some day, she wishes that their business will grow and, more importantly, that it will generate employment in the community.

loans.use: Majority will be for buying materials for furniture making and small amount will support her buying and selling of relief goods.

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene A. hails from the beautiful city of Antipolo, Rizal Province in the Philippines. She is 39 years old and  is determined and full of faith, as mother of a daughter, to get out of poverty. She is married to Renaldo, who is a 39-year-old driver.

With her dream to step out of poverty, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, in 2007. Her previous loans were used as capital for her business, in which she sells live chickens and chicken feathers. The live chickens are used as raw material for fried chicken. The feathers are used for decorations and costumes, and are in demand in dress shops and in the market.

The business went well and brought her enough income to sustain her family's needs. Now on her 4th loan, she proposes a loan of 20,000 pesos as additional capital for reselling live chickens and chicken feathers.

She is optimistic that, with her business, she will be able to achieve her dream of sending her only child to school and be able to expand her business.

loans.use: As additional capital for resale of live chicken and of chicken feathers.

loans.name: Thuoc

texts.en:
Thuộc Lê T. was born in 1959. (id: 010117100016). She lives in Xom Hau, Uy No, Dong Anh with her husband and four children. Her two older daughters are married; her son is a drive; her youngest daughter is a student. 

Her husband is a carpenter, and makes chairs, beds and tables. Thuộc Lê T. sells pork in the market. She has a monthly income of about 3,000,000 VND. She has been a member of SEDA for 3 years. This time, Thuộc Lê T. wants to borrow 5,886,000 VND to support her retail business. She hopes for the opportunity to continue participating in the program for a long time.

loans.use: For retailing purposes

loans.name: Wennelyn

texts.en:
Wennely is a young mother to two kids. She is married to Chito, 27 years old and a rickshaw driver. Even with her young age, she opened her eyes to a much wider perspective in life. She dreams of pulling her family out of poverty. She lives in Antipoly City, Rizal province in the Philippines.

As a woman of hope, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, in 2005. While her husband is engaged with driving a rickshaw, she thinks of a business which can help her husband in earning money. Considering that she has young children, she decided to open a Sari-sari Store (General Store) in their house. The business ran well and her neighbors became her regular customers.

Now on her 6th loan, she is requesting 20,000 pesos as additional capital for her store. The loan will be used to pay for cases of soft drinks, liquors, rice, charcoal and many other groceries for the store.

She is optimistic that with her growing business, she will be able to save for the future of her children, especially the education expenses, and hopeful of expanding her business.

loans.use: To expand store inventory

loans.name: Hidaya

texts.en:
Hidaya is a member of the Mwande borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is 42 years old, married, and the mother of 6 children. Her children are aged 30, 20, 22, 15, 13, and 10 years. She also cares for 3 other dependents.

Hidaya started her own food business selling rice and tomatoes 12 years ago. She works 14 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 180,000 Tanzanian shillings (about $135 US).

This is Hidaya’s second loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 250,000 shillings in order to buy more commodities. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Hidaya hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities for resale

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a member of the Mwande borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is a 41 years old, married, and the mother of 2 children. Her children are ages 26 and 16 years. She also cares for 2 other dependents.

Joyce started her own business selling clothes 10 years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 200,000 Tanzanian Shillings (about $150 US).

This is Joyce’s second loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 350,000 shillings in order to buy more clothes. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Joyce hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy clothes for resale

loans.name: Selina

texts.en:
Selina is a member of the Uamsho borrower group in Kola, Mororgoro. She is 32 years old, married, and the mother of 3 children. Her children are 16, 13, and 8 years old.

Selina started her own business selling bananas 2 years ago. She works 8 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 60,000 Tanzanian Shillings (about $45).

This is Selina’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 150,000 shillings in order to buy more bananas. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Selina hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy bananas for resale

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a member of the Upendo North borrower group in Kinyanambo. She is 22 years old, single, and has a one-year-old child.

Grace started her own business selling clothes one year ago. She works 10 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 70,000 Tanzanian shillings (about $53 US).

This is Grace’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 shillings in order to buy more clothes. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Grace hopes to expand her business and save more money.

loans.use: To buy clothes for resale

loans.name: Emeline

texts.en:
Emeline S. is a 40-year-old woman who has been raising her 12-year-old twins all by herself after her separation from her husband. She and her children live in Patria, Pandan in the province of Antique. Though their village is far from the market and the main municipality, Emeline never allowed these circumstances to hinder her from earning money. She had been selling a variety of cooked food in her neighborhood, even reaching houses farther away in their village. She is used to walking through the rough and narrow road covered with trees to make sure that when she comes back home, she brings money that the children need for school. Neither rain, the heat of the sun, nor tiredness is an excuse for her to stop her from what she has been doing.

Emeline's family owns a small land that can be used in planting rice. However, this land has not been productive because there was no business capital to start with. The vision of profiting from this kind of business made her join ASHI and take a loan. From then on, her farming business was born and with the help of her family, she tries to maintain it together with her food selling business.

Having her family, her own children, and ASHI, Emeline is secure for she can have her own business, which can enable her to send all of her children to college and give them a better life.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and pesticides and to support her food selling business

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a member of the Ikweta center borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is a 33-year-old woman. She is married and the mother of three children. Her children are aged 10, 3, and 14 years. She also cares for four other dependents. 

 Fatuma started her own retail business selling maize four years ago. She works 10 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 50,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Fatuma’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 TSH in order to buy more maize. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Fatuma hopes to save money, get more food for her family and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more maize

loans.name: Donata

texts.en:
Donata is a member of the Ikweta center borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is a 42-year-old woman, married, and the mother of four children. Her children are aged 20, 16, 13, and 8 years. She also cares for four other dependents. 
Donata started her own grocery business selling beer and soda one year ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 50,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Donata’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 TSH in order to buy more beer and soda. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Donata hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more beer and soda

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita B. is from the village of Lantay, Valencia City Bukidnon. She is 52 years old. Teresita is married and has 9 school-aged children. To make a living, Teresita owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Teresita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used as additional business capital. Teresita is requesting a new loan which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Teresita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children and supplement her income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ajesca

texts.en:
Ajesca is a member of the Mgodi center borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is a 29-year-old woman, married, and the mother of two children. Her children are aged 8 and 3 years.
 
Ajesca started her own tailoring business two years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 60,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Ajesca’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 TSH in order to buy more material. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Ajesca hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more material

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is a member of the Mgodi North borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is a 35-year-old woman, married, and the mother of four children. Her children are aged 14, 10, 4, and 2 years.

Veronica started her own food business selling tomatoes, salt, and bananas five years ago. She works 14 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 80,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Veronica’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 TSH in order to buy more tomatoes, bananas, and salt. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Veronica hopes to save money and expand.

loans.use: To buy more tomatoes, bananas, and salt

loans.name: Elenita

texts.en:
Elenita B. is from the village of Lantay, Valencia Bukidnon. She is 33 years old. Elenita is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Elenita owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Elenita has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Elenita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elenita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. Elenita is requesting a new loan which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Elenita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children and supplement her income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Grace Wanjiku

texts.en:
Grace K. is a 31-year-old single mother of one. She lives with her son Fredrick in Mariakani where she operates a retail shop and a grocery store.

Her business is located on a main road at the Mariakani Shopping Centre and has been in operation for five years.  This will be Grace's first loan from KADET, and with the 20,000 Kenyan shilling loan she plans to purchase more peas, beans, and maize for her shop in order to meet customer demand.

Grace's dream is to become a leading wholesaler in the area, and to purchase a pickup van to transport inventory she buys from from her main suppliers to her shop.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To expand the inventory of a small general store.

loans.name: Marisa

texts.en:
Marisa G. is from the village of Lantay, Valencia Bukidnon. She is 28 years old. Marisa is married and has 3 infant-aged children. To make a living, Marisa owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail business. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling seafood products  including fish and shrimp. She also offers spices like onions, garlic, and others in the local community. Marisa has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marisa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marisa is requesting a loan which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Marisa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Husna

texts.en:
Husna is a member of the Mgodi center borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is a 39-year-old woman, married, and the mother of three children. Her children are aged 21, 18, and 11 years.

Husna started her own clothing business selling kitenge and kanga (fabric) one year ago. She works 6 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 60,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Husna’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 TSH in order to buy more kanga, and vitenge (fabric). With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Husna hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale
